Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Reseach Grant: The Impact of Engagement, Capacity and Continuity in Preparing Elementary Education Pre-Service Teachers for Science Teaching.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Virginia State University HBCU-UP Broadening Participation Research in STEM Education project is entitled The Impact of Engagement, Capacity and Continuity in Preparing Elementary Education Pre-Service Teachers for Science Teaching. The proposed effort is a partnership between the School of Engineering, Science and Technology and the School of Education and is designed to use the Engagement, Capacity and Continuity (ECC) theory to determine the impact of the current elementary education program on preservice teachers' interest, motivation, and confidence to teach science. The objectives are (1) to examine and enhance innovative instructional practices for preservice elementary education students in order to increase their scholarly interest, awareness, and motivation to teach science; (2) to examine and enhance innovative instructional practices for preservice elementary students in order to increase their capacity as scholars; and (3) to examine the institution?s current systematic practices and underlying support systems for elementary preservice education teachers.

Using the ECC Trilogy for Student Success as the conceptual framework, the study proposes to validate and expand the ECC model for determining the essential program components to prepare highly qualified and successful minority elementary preservice science teachers and to retain them in the profession. The model has been validated with pre-college populations but not with the targeted population for this study. The study builds on existing knowledge about the difficulties beginning teachers encounter when faced with the realities of teaching and how habits of mind can negatively impact K-6 science teaching and further acerbate the achievement gap. The aim is to produce new knowledge to predict the success of preservice teachers for science teaching. The study can potentially enhance the preparation of underrepresented preservice teachers and build capacity in the teaching and learning of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this study was to determine what individual and institutional factors are needed for preparation of elementary preservice teachers to become successful science teachers. The intellectual merit of this project was based upon the following question: How can teacher preparation programs best ensure that they are preparing teachers who have the necessary personal dispositions (e.g., interest, awareness, and motivation), content knowledge and skills, and access to institutional and programmatic resources? The Engagement, Capacity, and Continuity (ECC) Trilogy for Student Success served as the conceptual framework for this proposed study. Jolly, Campbell, and Perlman (2004) found that three broad conditions—Engagement, Capacity and Continuity—must exist simultaneously for student success in sciences and quantitative disciplines. Engagement involves student awareness, interest and motivation while capacity is concerned with the student possession of skills and knowledge needed to program. Continuity is concerned with having the necessary resources to advance. This factor is not related to student abilities, but is the responsibility of a student’s institution or educational system to provide the tools necessary to student success.

Research instrument and data collection tools for this study included the Science Teaching Efficacy Belief Instrument (STEBI-B), the Knowledge, Skills, and Dispositions (KSD) survey, the Pedagogical Content Knowledge and Confidence (PCKC) Survey, and focus group interviews. The STEBI-B, developed in 1990, is a 23-item self-assessment of preservice elementary teacher’s self-efficacy that utilized utilizing a 5 point Likert-type scale.  The Knowledge, Skills, and Dispositions (KSD) survey was developed by the principal investigators to capture perceptions of science educators and district supervisors on what teacher attitudes and interests were needed for successful science teaching. The survey asked for respondents to indicate the level of importance of the knowledge, skills, and dispositions needed by elementary teachers when teaching science. Results of this survey were used to inform VSU’s development of a conceptual framework for its teacher-training program. The Science Pedagogical Content Knowledge and Confidence (PCKC) survey was developed by the principal investigators, and designed around two constructs: knowledge and confidence.  The survey contained 20 items each related to students’ knowledge of the science content and confidence in their ability to teach the subject.  

Consistent with the literature, results from this study indicates science methods courses can enhance interest and motivation (i.e., engagement) of preservice elementary teachers to become successful science teachers.  It can also improve the skills and knowledge (i.e., capacity) needed for successful science teaching. The survey results showed improvements on the pre- post-surveys designed to measure on the knowledge and confidence items. Science methods courses improved participant’s ability to design inquiry-based lesson plans, and encouraged their ability to select appropriate manipulatives for hands-on science lessons.

 Survey results indicated that teachers and university personnel in the field believed that this universities’ teacher education conceptual framework is comprehensive and well-aligned to current beliefs. However while the university is providing the resources (i.e., continuity) needed for successful teaching, a suggested critical area for improvement included providing higher quality field experiences that demonstrate  research-based science teaching in elementary education. Preservice teachers indicated that field based observations did not provide exposure to effective science teaching. Participants reported observation of limited and rushed science lessons that were poorly integrated with other subject areas. The ECC model was originally intended to address issues of K-12 student continuation in STEM fields. This study is one of the first to test the boundaries of the ECC Theory to identify those individual and institutional factors critical for the preparation of effective elementary education science teachers.
